resources.string: Tabletop mode. Place your device with the charging port to the left. To update dot position, hold down six fingers.
There is no other keyboard enabled – go to keyboard settings
Swipe up with three fingers for more options
TalkBack braille keyboard – for help, visit g.co/help/braille
Updating dot position. First, let’s record the dots on your left hand. Touch and hold the screen with the middle three fingers of your left hand.
Updating dot position. First, let’s record the dots on your right hand. Touch and hold the screen with the middle three fingers of your right hand.
Updated positions for dots 1, 2 and 3. Next, let’s record the dots on your right hand. Touch and hold the screen with the middle three fingers of your right hand.
Updated positions for dots 1, 2 and 3. Next, let’s record the dots on your left hand. Touch and hold the screen with the middle three fingers of your left hand.
Couldn’t update dot position. Touch and hold the screen with six fingers. Then try again.

To use the braille keyboard, open your regular keyboard, then tap the \'choose keyboard\' icon %1$s (usually at the bottom-right corner). Select \'%2$s\'.

If you don’t see an option to switch keyboards, try installing %3$s, the Google Keyboard.

1. Turn on braille keyboard: Tap Settings below. On the next screen, turn on \'%1$s\'.

2. Use braille keyboard: Open your regular keyboard, then tap the \'choose keyboard\' icon %2$s (usually at the bottom-right corner). Select \'%1$s\'.

If you don’t see an option to switch keyboards, try installing %3$s, the Google Keyboard.
Each pressed dot is part of the input, even if the dot is released before other dots
Swap the dot positions, so that dots one and four trade places, for example
To add a space, swipe right
For a new line, swipe right with two fingers
To delete a word, swipe left with two fingers
To hide the keyboard, swipe down with two fingers
To switch to the next keyboard, swipe down with three fingers
To submit text, swipe up with two fingers
For help and other options, swipe up with three fingers
Hold device with screen away from you (screen-away mode)
Place device flat on a table (tabletop mode)
Adapt to how you hold the device
Your device doesn’t support braille keyboard
Your device doesn’t support enough touch points. For more information, contact your device manufacturer.
Turn on TalkBack to use braille keyboard
Resume TalkBack to use braille keyboard
When TalkBack is on, you can tap your screen to enter braille symbols.

With the braille keyboard, you can tap your screen to enter 6-dot braille.

You’re using Unified English Braille. To switch your typing language, go to TalkBack settings.

To type braille, you need to hold and use your phone differently.
You won’t be able to use regular TalkBack gestures in the braille keyboard.\n\nTo get started, let’s set up the position of the six braille dots when you type.
Starting now, you won’t be able to use regular TalkBack gestures. TalkBack isn’t available while using the braille keyboard.
To start, hold your phone like this, with the screen facing away from you.
Tap dot 1 with your %1$s to type the letter \'A\'
Next, try typing the letters B, C and D
To delete a letter, swipe left
To add a space, swipe right
To hide keyboard, swipe down with two fingers
To switch to your other keyboard, swipe down with three fingers
To type in tabletop mode, put your phone flat on the table
To finish tutorial, swipe up with three fingers
Starting now, you won’t be able to use regular TalkBack gestures. TalkBack isn’t available while using the braille keyboard.\n\n%1$s

First, turn your phone so that the screen is facing away from you.

Next, rotate the phone horizontally to landscape position. Your hands should grip the short ends of the phone. Your right hand should hold the end with the USB port. Rest your three middle fingers on the screen, and use your little finger and thumb to support the phone.

When you’re ready, double tap the screen to continue.

To exit braille keyboard, swipe down toward the ground with three fingers. This switches back to your original keyboard.

Your phone is in a vertical position. To continue, rotate your phone horizontally so that the long side is on the bottom. Then turn the screen to face away from you. When you’re ready, double tap the screen to continue.

Keep the screen faced away from you. Hold your phone in both hands, on the short edges of the phone, so that the middle three fingers of each hand can touch the screen.\n\nYour %1$s should be on dot 1. Now, tap dot 1 to type the letter ‘A’.
Tap dot 1 with your %1$s to type \'A\'
To delete a letter, swipe left. Try it now.
To add a space, swipe right. Try it now.
To hide the keyboard, swipe down with two fingers. Try it now.
Hide keyboard. Usually, this will hide the keyboard. The braille keyboard will stay open because you’re still in the tutorial.
To switch to your other keyboard, swipe down with three fingers. Try it now.
Next keyboard. Usually, this will switch to the next keyboard. This time, you’re staying in the braille keyboard because you’re still in the tutorial.
You can also type in tabletop mode by placing your phone flat on a table. To finish the tutorial, swipe up with three fingers, and find the finish tutorial option
The options menu is open. Flip your phone back so that it’s facing you and hold it normally. You can now use regular TalkBack gestures to navigate. Swipe right to see more options.
%s\nPlace your device flat on a table. Then, touch and hold the screen with the middle three fingers of each hand in a position that’s comfortable for you to type.
Place your device flat on a table. Then, touch and hold the screen with the middle three fingers of each hand in a position that’s comfortable for you to type.
You can also type by placing your phone flat on a table. Try it now. If you don’t have a table nearby, skip ahead by swiping down.
Showing braille keyboard. Turn your phone so that the screen is facing away from you. Rotate the phone horizontally to landscape position. Then start typing.
